plants.watering: Newly planted roses should be watered every 3-4 days, while established roses can be watered once a week.
plants.description: Woody perennial flowering plants belonging to the genus Rosa in the family Rosaceae. There are over 300 wild species of roses, with tens of thousands of different cultivated varieties (cultivars) grown worldwide for their beautiful, often fragrant flowers. These plants can take the form of erect shrubs, climbing plants, or trailing plants, and their stems are frequently covered in sharp prickles.

plants.watering: Every 2-3 weeks, allow soil to dry completely
plants.description: Succulent plant known for its medicinal gel used for skin care and burns.

plants.watering: One or two times per week, allow soil to dry
plants.description: Woody vine or shrub known for its vibrant, colorful bracts that surround its small, true flowers.
Perennial Herb, Found on every continent except Antarctica.

plants.watering: Every 1 to 2 weeks, when soil looks dry
plants.description: Is a shrub with fragrant, evergreen, needle-like leaves and white, pink, purple, or blue flowers.

plants.watering: Once a week or every 10 days
plants.description: Considered perennial shrubs or herbaceous perennials, depends on the species.

plants.watering: Water your cactus every 2-4 weeks during the growing season. In the fall and winter, when the cactus is dormant, reduce watering to once every 4-6 weeks.
plants.sunlight: Indirect sunlight, sudden exposure to direct sun can cause sunburn, leading to infection and death
plants.description: Cacti are a family of flowering, succulent plants, primarily native to the Americas, known for their water-storing stems, areoles (specialized buds that produce spines, flowers, and branches), and the absence of true leaves, which are typically modified into protective spines or hairs to reduce water loss

plants.watering: Once or twice a week, in the morning, let soil dry between waterings
plants.sunlight: Indirect sunlight, partial shade, morning sun, afternoon shade
plants.description: Is a deciduous shrub native to East Asia, especially Japan. It is known for its large, long-blooming summer flowers, which grow in rounded "mophead" or flattened "lacecap" clusters.

plants.watering: For new Magnolia trees, twice a week for the first few years, ensuring the soil remains moist.
plants.sunlight: Full sun to partial shade, at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily
plants.description: Magnolias are spreading evergreen or deciduous trees or shrubs characterised by large fragrant flowers, which may be bowl-shaped or star-shaped, in shades of white, pink, purple, green, or yellow.

plants.watering: Water once a week, keep soil slightly moist but not soggy
plants.description: Tropical plant with large, glossy leaves featuring characteristic natural holes, also known as the Swiss Cheese Plant.

treatments.treatmentDescription: Fertilization with K (potassium) and P (phosphorus) during their active growing season in spring and summer The best time to fertilize is when the plant shows signs of active growth, like forming new buds, but avoid fertilizing during winter dormancy.

For herbaceous plants, apply a balanced or low-nitrogen fertilizer, such as a granular type, in early spring for annuals and when plants emerge from dormancy for perennials, or use compost as a natural slow-release option. Water immediately after application to avoid burning and promote absorption.

Protection from extreme temperatures during the active growing season (spring and summer), fertilize with a diluted, balanced liquid fertilizer. Ensure containers have drainage holes to prevent root rot from overwatering.

Consistent maintenance practices such as proper watering, regular pruning, and applying mulch to retain soil moisture and suppress weeds. You should also monitor for pests and diseases, applying pesticides or fungicides if necessary, and provide nutrients through balanced fertilizers or soil amendments to support plant health.

Organic option like well-rotted manure or compost, applied annually in early spring and potentially again in fall to encourage robust growth and abundant blooms, not excessive foliage. When applying, scatter the fertilizer around the plant's base, gently incorporating it into the soil, or create a small trench for organic materials.
treatments.timeOfYear: Early spring and again after each flush of flowers, until late summer

treatments.treatmentDescription: use a slow-release, low-nitrogen (low-N) fertilizer during its active growing season (spring/summer) at half strength. Apply it around the base of the plant on moist soil, not directly on the cactus body, and avoid fertilizing during winter dormancy or extreme heat.
treatments.timeOfYear: Early to mid-spring, or late fall after first frost

treatments.treatmentDescription: Consistent maintenance practices such as proper watering, regular pruning, and applying mulch to retain soil moisture and suppress weeds. You should also monitor for pests and diseases, applying pesticides or fungicides if necessary, and provide nutrients through balanced fertilizers or soil amendments to support plant health.

Consistent maintenance practices such as proper watering, regular pruning, and applying mulch to retain soil moisture and suppress weeds. You should also monitor for pests and diseases, applying pesticides or fungicides if necessary, and provide nutrients through balanced fertilizers or soil amendments to support plant health.

Apply a slow-release, balanced fertilizer or organic compost in early spring before new growth appears, spreading it out to the drip line. You can also fertilize with liquid options up to three times during the growing season. Always water thoroughly after fertilizing, and be mindful of the tree's sensitive roots by avoiding unnecessary fertilization unless the tree shows weak growth.
